results.title: Miquette et Sa Mere = Miquette and Her Mother
results.brief_description:
Miquette aspires to be an actress. She runs off with a nobleman who promises to make her a star. When Miquette’s mother searches for her wandering daughter, she finds the girl working with a ragtag touring company. The mother takes a job with the troupe to keep the lecherous nobleman away from Miquette. The film works best as a portrait of a provincial theatre in the 19th century.

Credits: Producer, Paul Joly ; director, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writer, Henri-Georges Clouzot ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Albert Lasry ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Bourvil, Daniele Delorme, Mireille Perrey, Saturnin Fabre, Pauline Carton, Paul Barge, Leonce Corne, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Olivier Hussenot, Philippe Nicaud, Pierre Olaf, Maurice Schutz, Louis Seigner.

results.title: Qui? = Who?
results.brief_description:
A car rides off a cliff. The female passenger survives the ordeal, her male companion, the driver does not. The brother of the dead man takes the young woman back to his place. Although he suspects her to have something to do with his brother’s death, he is inexplicably attracted to her. The police recovers the dead body and for a while the suspicions a laid to rest. But the ‘dead man’ reappears not long after 

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Leonard Keigel ; writers, Leonard Keigel, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Maurice Ronet, Simone Bach, Jacques Duby, Gabriele Tinti.

results.title: Dark angel
results.creator_credit: Sidney A. Franklin, Samuel Goldwyn and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of a World War I ravaged England, this superbly acted romantic drama is a true classic. Merle Oberon is a revelation as a reformed vamp torn between two men - Herbert Marshall and Frederic March, the latter having returned from the war blinded. The script was adapted by Lillian Hellman from the play by Guy Bolton (a.k.a R. B. Trevelyan).

results.title: Dr Petiot
results.creator_credit: Christian de Chalonge, Philippe Chapelier-Dehesdin, Alain Sarde, Canal+, Cine 5, Sara Films and MS Productions
results.brief_description: Michel Serrault gives an extraordinary perfomance as ‘Dr Petiot’, a serial killer who lured Jews into his trap by offering them protection from the Nazis. The film’s expressionistic quality, emphasised by the heavy make-up of Petiot, and the deep focus photography, gives the film a nightmare quality reminiscent of the early German silent horror films. Indeed the film opens with scenes from one such film, plunging us into a world of evil. Based on a true character, Serrault’s perfomance is chilling.

results.title: L'amour Fou = Mad Love
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jacques Rivette
results.brief_description:
“Rightly described by Dave Kehr as Jacques Rivette’s ‘breakthrough film, the first of his features to employ extreme length (252 minutes), a high degree of improvisation, and a formal contrast between film and theater,’ this rarely screened 1968 masterpiece is one of the great French films of the 60s. It centers on rehearsals for a production of Racine’s Andromaque and the doomed yet passionate relationship between a director and his actress wife, who leaves the production at the beginning of the film and then festers in paranoid isolation. The rehearsals, filmed by Rivette (in 35-millimeter) and by TV documentarist Andre S. Labarthe (in 16mm), are real, and the relationship between Kalfon and Ogier is fictional, but this only begins to describe the powerful interfacing of life and art that takes place over the film’s hypnotic, epic unfolding. In the rehearsal space Rivette cuts frequently between the 35- and 16-millimeter footage, juxtaposing two kinds of documentary reality; in the couple’s apartment, filmed only in 35, the oscillation between love and madness, passion and mistrust, builds to several terrifying and awesome climaxes in which the distinctions between life and theater, reality and fiction, become virtually irrelevant. In many ways this is Ogier’s richest, finest performance, and Kalfon keeps pace with her every step of the way. This film captures the dreams and desperation of the 60s like few others, and you emerge from it changed; it’s a life experience as much as a film experience. Rivette’s obsessional uses of real time and natural duration take some getting used to, but the experience becomes both mesmerizing and all-enveloping.” Reference: Jonathan Rosenbaum. Chicago Reader. Online. http://onfilm.chireader.com/

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jacques Rivette ; writers, Jacques Rivette, Marilu Parolini ; photography, Etienne Becker, Alain Levent ; music, Jean-Claude Eloy.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Josee Destoop, Celia, Andre S.-Labarthe.

results.title: Prenom Carmen = First Name Carmen
results.creator_credit: WDR La Sept Cinema and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description:
The plot involves a gang of thieves, a kidnapping and a certifiably burnt-out film director played by Godard. The central characters, Joseph and Carmen, are based on Jose and Carmen in Merimee’s story, with a Beethoven string quartet substituting for Bizet’s music. The conception of Carmen - the woman as a destructive, amoral force - is also close to that of Marianne/Anna Karina in ‘Pierrot le fou’. But typically, Godard is interested not in letting the narrative proceed so much as in brushing it aside. What Pauline Kael aptly calls “the pop clarity” of his sixties movies here gives way to an ambivalent art-cinema overlay on a mix of B-movie plot, a pessimistic wit and modernist-romantic introspection about the relationship between art and life. Awards: Venice Film Festival 1983 - Golden Lion.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard, Jean-Bernard Menoud ; writer, Anne-Marie Mieville ; editor, Jean-Luc Godard ; music, Ludwig Van Beethoven, Tom Waits.
Cast: Maruschka Detmers, Jacques Bonnaffe, Myriem Roussel, Christophe Odent, Jean-Luc Godard, Jacques Villeret, Hippolyte Girardot, Jean-Pierre Mocky.

results.title: The Girl can't help it
results.creator_credit: Frank Tashlin and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This wonderfully farcical comedy is the first big budget rock and roll movie of the fifties and features seventeen great songs of the era. Tom Ewell plays a down and out agent who is hired by a mobster to make a star out of his sex-pot girlfriend (Jayne Mansfield). Ewell gives her a rock and roll act in the hope of making the big time but Jayne yearns for the simple life and complications set in when she falls for Ewell, while searching for the perfect husband. Includes Little Richard, Eddie Cochran, Gene Vincent, Platters, Fats Domino and more. Also stars Edmond O’Brien.

results.title: Le Corbeau = the Raven
results.brief_description:
A small French village is plagued by a poison pen writer, whose principal target is the town doctor. The vitriolic letters wreak so much havoc that soon neighbour turns upon neighbour. Eventually, the doctor himself is suspected of writing the letters, cloaking himself in the respectability of his office. When the psychiatrist starts receiving letters as well, he decides to investigate. Concluding that his own wife is the culprit, he has her committed. But soon after, more letters arrive … ‘Le Corbeau’ is a realistic portrait of Occupied France and its obsession for petty bickering and vengeful denunciation. Produced by the German production company ‘Continental Films’ the film was condemned as unpatriotic after the Liberation, and director Henri-Georges Clouzot was banned from filmmaking until 1947. Le Corbeau’ was remade in Hollywood by Otto Preminger as ‘The 13th Letter’ (1951).

Credits: Producer: Rene Montis ; director: Henri-Georges Clouzot ; writers, Henri-Georges Clouzot, Louis Chavance ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Tony Aubin ; sound, William-Robert Sivel.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Micheline Francey, Ginette Leclerc, Roger Blin, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Pierre Bertin, Pierre Larquey, Jean Brochard, Helene Manson, Noel Roquevert, Louis Seigner, Sylvie.

results.title: Qui Etes-Vous Monsieur Sorge? = Who Are You, Mister Sorge?
results.brief_description:
This war time docudrama is based on real life events. Richard Sorge was from 1935 through 1943 working at the German embassy in Japan. Sorge was also a Russian spy, leaking out secret invasion plans in preparation for the anticipated Soviet takeover of Japan after the war. After his activities were uncovered, people say he was tried and hanged by the Japanese in 1944. Others suspect he may have been exchanged. His faithful secretary thinks Sorge paid for other people’s mistakes. The film attempts to discover the truth by following with great minutiae the last months of Sorge’s life.

Credits: Producer, Jean Cotet ; director, Yves Ciampi ; writers, Yves Ciampi, Rodolphe-Maurice Arlaud ; photography, Emile Villerbue, T. Ubukata ; music, Serge Nigg.
Cast: Thomas Holtzmann, Hans-Otto Meissner, Keiko Kishi, Nadine Basile, Jacques Berthier, Jesse Hahn.

results.title: Le Testament du Dr Cordelier = The Testament of Dr Cordelier (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
A series of brutal attacks, mainly on women and children, are traced to a mysterious Monsieur Opale, whom the respected Dr. Cordelier claims as a friend. One day, the doctor’s lawyer discovers that his client and Opale are one and the same, the doctor having created his alter ego by means of a drug. This re-telling of the Jekyll-Hyde legend adheres to Renoir’s long-standing ‘leitmotiv’ of the individual who must stand alone because he is incapable of conforming. The original Robert Louis Stevenson story is updated, making several pointed comments about the good/evil dichotomy of the modern world. Renoir used up to 8 cameras and 12 microphones which gives the film a fluid, rough-edged, spontaneous appeal. This production was first conceived as a live TV play. The director’s method of cutting only after each sequence allowed the actors to determine their own speed.

Credits: Producer, Albert Hollebecke ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Jean-Louis Barrault, Teddy Bilis, Michel Vitold, Jean Topart, Micheline Gray, Jaque Catelain, Gaston Modot, Regine Blaess.

Credits: Producer, Albert Hollebecke ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Jean-Louis Barrault, Teddy Bilis, Michel Vitold, Jean Topart, Micheline Gray, Jaque Catelain, Gaston Modot, Regine Blaess.
